thread.title: British GQ writer asks if Obama could kill Trump (but don’t worry — it was just ‘a joke’)
thread.title_full: British GQ writer asks if Obama could kill Trump (but don’t worry — it was just ‘a joke’)

author: Sarah D.
title: British GQ writer asks if Obama could kill Trump (but don’t worry — it was just ‘a joke’)
text:
— Dan Ornelas (@DanielMOrnelas) January 11, 2017 
This election cycle has shown an unflattering light on a lot of people, but the media may very well have come out looking worse than anyone. And that’s thanks in no small part to people like Rupert Myers. 
Myers, political correspondent for British GQ and the Telegraph, decided it would be a good idea to tweet this out earlier today: Members of the press continue to adjust to the post-Nov. 8 world with commendable grace and charm. pic.twitter.com/jUdpe99GN0 
— T. Becket Adams (@BecketAdams) January 11, 2017 
Myers’ tweet didn’t stay up for long. Why did you delete this tweet, @RupertMyers ? 
Imagine a conservative said this in '08 about Obama. pic.twitter.com/4E7HhFYAKQ 
— Harry Khachatrian (@Harry1T6) January 11, 2017 @Harry1T6 it was a joke that I quickly realised could be taken out of context. you've proved my point 
— Rupert Myers (@RupertMyers) January 11, 2017 
Ah. So it’s readers’ fault for failing to get his crappy “joke.” Myers didn’t delete the tweet because he felt bad about it; he did it because he didn’t like being called out for his jackassery. LOL guys it's really not that slow a news day. I was just wondering if the president could pardon himself 😂 pic.twitter.com/i6GNmaB9c3 
— Rupert Myers (@RupertMyers) January 11, 2017 
Except that’s not what he asked. And now, he’s paying for it: I'm in the middle of a small tweetstorm being attacked by truly daft & entirely humourless Trump supporters pic.twitter.com/2I2jXnMWkh 
— Rupert Myers (@RupertMyers) January 11, 2017 
What a shame. 
— Scills Matthews (@scillsygirl) January 11, 2017 You called for the president elect to be murdered…… https://t.co/aWs2aMl2sU
